div.p: The names of such as acted.
TO MY WORTHILY RESPECTED FRIENDS, Nathaniel Finch, Iohn Ford, Esquires; Mr. Henry Blvnt, Mr. Robert Ellice, and all the rest of the Noble Society of Grayes Inn.

div.head: To my Honoured Friend, Master Iohn Ford, on his Lovers Melancholy. By Donne, G.
div.l: If that thou thinkest these lines thy worth can raise,
Thou dost mistake; my liking is no praise:
Nor can I think thy Judgment is so ill,
To seek for Bays from such a barren Quill:
Let your true Critic, that can judge and mend,
Allow thy Sceanes and Style: I, as a friend
That knows thy worth, do only stick my name,
To show my Love, not to advance thy Fame.

div.head: To his worthy Friend, the Author, Master Iohn Ford. By Singleton, W.
div.l: I write not to thy Play: I will not begin
To throw a censure upon what hath been
By the best approved; It can nor fear, nor want
The Rage, or Liking of the Ignorant.
Nor seek I Fame for Thee, when thine own Pen
Hath forced a praise long since, from knowing Men.
I speak my thoughts, and wish unto the Stage
A glory from thy studies; that the Age
May be indebted to Thee, for Reprieve
Of purer language, and that Spite may grieve
To see It self out-done. When Thou art read,
The Theatre may hope Arts are not dead,
Though long concealed; that Poet-Apes may fear
To vent their weakness, mend, or quite forbear.
This I dare promise; and keep this in store;
As thou hast done enough, Thou canst do more.

div.head: To the Author, Master Iohn Ford. By Howorth, H.
div.l: Black choler, Reasons over-flowing Spring,
Where thirsty Lovers drink, or any Thing,
Passion, the restless current of dull plaints
Affords their thoughts, who deem lost beauties, Saints:
Here their best Lectures read, collect, and see
Various conditions of Humanity
Highly enlightened by thy Muses rage;
Yet all so couched, that they adorned the Stage.
Shun Phocions blushes thou; for sure to please
It is no sin, then what is thy disease?
Judgments applause? effeminated smiles?
Studie's delight? thy wit mistrust beguiles:
Established Fame will thy Physician be,
(Write but again) to cure thy Jealousy.

div.head: Of the Lovers Melancholy. By Unknown
div.l: It is not the Language, nor the fore-placed Rimes
Of Friends, that shall commend to after-times
The Lovers Melancholy: Its own worth
Without a borrowed praise, shall set it forth.

sp.speaker: THE PROLOGVE.
sp.l: To tell ye (Gentlemen) in what true sense
The Writer, Actors, or the audience
Should mold their Judgements for a Play, might draw
Truth into Rules, but we have no such law.
Our Writer, for himself would have ye know,
That in his following Sceanes, he doth not owe
To others Fancies, nor hath lain in wait
For any stolen Invention, from whose height
He might commend his own, more than the right
A Scholar claims, may warrant for delight.
It is Arts scorn, that some of late have made
The Noble use of Poetry a Trade.
For your parts (Gentlemen) to quite his pains,
Yet you will please, that as you meet with strains
Of lighter mixtures, but to cast your eye
Rather upon the main, than on the bye.
His hopes stand firm, and we shall find it true,
The Lovers Melancholy cured by you.

div2.head: Actus I. Scena I.

sp.speaker: Menaphon.
sp.l: Dangers? How mean you dangers? That so courtly
You gratulate my safe return from dangers?

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: From Travails (noble Sir.)

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: These are delights,
If my experience hath not Truant-like
Misspent the time, which I have strove to use,
For bettering my mind with observation.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: As I am modest, I protest it is strange:
But is it possible?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: To bestride
The frothy foams of Neptunes surging waves,
When blustering Boreas tosseth up the deep,
And thumps a thunder bounce?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Sweet Sir, it is nothing,
Straight comes a Dolphin playing near your ship,
Heaving his crooked back up, and presents
A Feather-bed, to waft ye to the shore,
As easily as if you slept in the Court.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: Indeed, is it true, I pray?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I will not stretch
Your Faith upon the Teinters, prithee Pelias,
Where didst thou learn this language?

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: I this language?
Alas, Sir, we that study words and forms
Of complement, must fashion all discourse,
According to the nature of the subject.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: But I am silent, now appears a Sun,
Whose shadow I adore.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: My honoured Father.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: From mine eyes, son, son of my care, my love,
The joys that bid thee welcome, do too much
speak me a child.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: O Princely Sir, your hand.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Perform your duties where you owe them first,
I dare not be so sudden in the pleasures,
Thy presence hath brought home.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Here thou still findest
A Friend as noble (Menaphon) as when
Thou leftest at thy departure.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Yes, I know it,
To him I owe more service. --

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Pray give leave,
He shall attend your entertainments soon,
Next day, and next day, for an hour or two,
I would engross him only.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: You are both dismissed.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: Your creature, and your Servant.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, I will not say, Thou art welcome,
That is the common road of common friends,
I am glad I have thee here -- O, I want words
To let thee know my heart.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It is pieced to mine.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Yes, it is, as firmly, as that holy thing
Called Friendship can unite it. Menaphon,
My Menaphon: now all the goodly blessings,
That can create a Heaven on earth, dwell with thee.
Twelve months we have been sundered, but henceforth
We never more will part, till that sad hour,
In which death leaves the one of us behind,
To see the others funerals performed.
Let us now a while be free. How have thy travails
Disburdened thee abroad of discontents?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Such cure as sick men find in changing beds,
I found in change of Airs; the fancy flattered
My hopes with ease, as theirs do, but the grief
Is still the same.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Such is my case at home.
Cleophyla, thy Kinswoman, that Maid
Of sweetness and humility, more pities
Her Fathers poor afflictions, than the tide
Of my complaints.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Thamasta, my great Mistress,
Your Princely Sister, hath, I hope ere this,
Confirmed affection on some worthy choice.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Not any, Menaphon. Her bosom yet
Is intermured with Ice, though by the truth
Of love, no day hath ever past, wherein
I have not mentioned thy deserts, thy constancy
Thy -- Come, in troth I dare not tell thee what,
Lest thou mightst think I fawned upon a sin
Friendship was never guilty of; for flattery
Is monstrous in a true friend.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Does the Court
Wear the old looks too?

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: If thou meanest the Prince,
It does, he is the same melancholy man,
He was at his Fathers death, sometimes speaks sense,
But seldom mirth; will smile, but seldom laugh;
Will lend an ear to business, deal in none;
Gaze upon Revels, Antic Fopperies,
But is not moved; will sparingly discourse,
Hear music; but what most he takes delight in,
Are handsome pictures; one so young, and goodly,
So sweet in his own nature, any Story
Hath seldom mentioned.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Why should such as I am,
Groan under the light burthens of small sorrows,
When as a Prince, so potent, cannot shun
Motions of passion? To be man (my Lord)
Is to be but the exercise of cares
In several shapes; as miseries do grow,
They alter as men's forms; but how, none know.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: This little Isle of Cyprus sure abounds
In greater wonders, both for change and fortune,
Than any you have seen abroad.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Than any
I have observed abroad: all Countries else
To a free eye and mind yield something rare;
And I for my part, have brought home one Jewel
Of admirable value.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Jewel, Menaphon?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: A Jewel, my Amethus, a fair Youth;
A Youth, whom if I were but superstitious,
I should repute an Excellence more high,
Than mere creations are, to add delight.
I will tell ye how I found him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Passing from Italy to Greece, the Tales
Which Poets of an elder time have feigned
To glorify their Tempo, bred in me
Desire of visiting that Paradise.
To Thessaly I came, and living private,
Without acquaintance of more sweet companions,
Than the old Inmates to my love, my thoughts;
I day by day frequented silent Groves,
And solitary Walks. One morning early
This accident encountered me: I heard
The sweetest and most ravishing contention,
That Art of Nature ever were at strife in.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: I cannot yet conceive, what you infer
By Art and Nature.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I shall soon resolve ye.
A sound of music touched mine ears, or rather
Indeed entranced my soul: as I stole nearer,
Invited by the melody, I saw
This Youth, this fair-faced Youth, upon his Lute
With strains of strange variety and harmony,
Proclaiming (as it seemed) so bold a challenge
To the clear Choristers of the Woods, the Birds,
That as they flocked about him, all stood silent,
Wondering at what they heard. I wondered too.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: And so do I, good, -- on.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: A Nightingale.
Natures best skilled Musician undertakes
The challenge, and for every several strain
The well-shaped Youth could touch, she sung her down;
He could not run Division with more Art
Upon his quaking Instrument, than she,
The Nightingale did with her various notes
Reply too, for a voice, and for a sound,
Amethus, it is much easier to believe
That such they were, than hope to hear again.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: How did the Rivals part?

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: You term them rightly,
For they were Rivals, and their Mistress harmony.
Some time thus spent, the young man grew at last
Into a pretty anger, that a bird
Whom Art had never taught Cliffs, Moods, or Notes,
Should vie with him for mastery, whose study
Had busied many hours to perfect practise:
To end the controversy, in a rapture,
Upon his Instrument he plays so swiftly,
So many voluntaries, and so quick,
That there was curiosity and cunning,
Concord in discord, lines of differing method
Meeting in one full Centre of delight.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Now for the bird.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: The bird ordained to be
Musics first Martyr, strove to imitate
These several sounds: which, when her warbling throat
Failed in, for grief, down dropped she on his Lute,
And brake her heart; it was the quaintest sadness,
To see the Conqueror upon her Hearse,
To weep a funeral Elegy of tears,
That trust me (my Amethus) I could chide
Mine own unmanly weakness, that made me
A fellow-mourner with him.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: I believe thee.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: He looks upon the trophies of his Art,
Then sighed, then wiped his eyes, then sighed, and cried,
Alas poor creature: I will soon revenge
This cruelty upon the Author of it;
Henceforth this Lute guilty of innocent blood,
Shall never more betray a harmless peace
To an untimely end: and in that sorrow,
As he was bashing it against a tree,
I suddenly stepped in.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Thou hast discoursed
A truth of mirth and pity.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: I reprieved
The intended execution with entreaties,
And interruption: but (my Princely friend)
It was not strange, the music of his hand
Did over-match birds, when his voice and beauty,
Youth, carriage and discretion, must, from men
Endued with reason, ravish admiration:
From me they did.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: But is this miracle
Not to be seen?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I won him by degrees
To choose me his Companion whence he is,
Or who, as I durst modestly inquire,
So gently he would woo not to make known:
Only for reasons to himself reserved.
He told me, that some remnant of his life
Was to be spent in Travail; for his fortunes,
They were nor mean, nor riotous, his friends
Not published to the world, though not obscure:
His Country, Athens; and his name, Parthenophill.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Came he with you to Cyprus?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Willingly.
The fame of our young melancholy Prince,
Meleanders rare distractions, the obedience
Of young Cleophila, Thamasta's glory,
Your matchless friendship, and my desperate love
Prevailed with him, and I have lodged him privately
In Famagosta.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Now thou art doubly welcome:
I will not lose the sight of such a rarity
For one part of my hopes. When do ye intend
To visit my great-spirited Sister.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: May I
Without offence?

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Without offence? Parthenophill
Shall find a worthy entertainment too.
Thou art not still a coward.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: She is too excellent,
And I too low in merit.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: I will prepare
A noble welcome. And (friend) ere we part,
Unload to thee an over-charged heart.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: I will not court the madness of the times,
Nor fawn upon the Riots that embalm
Our wanton Gentry, to preserve the dust
Of their affected vanities in coffins
Of memorable shame; when Common-wealths
Totter and reel from that nobility
And ancient virtue, which renowns the great,
Who steer the Helm of government, while Mushrooms
Grow up, and make new laws to licence folly:
Why should not I, a May-game, scorn the weight
Of my sunk fortunes? snarl at the vices
Which rot the Land, and without fear or wit
Be mine own Antic? It is a sport to live
When life is irksome, if we will not hug
Prosperity in others, and contemn
Affliction in ourselves. This Rule is certain,
"He that pursues his safety from the School
"Of State, must learn to be mad man, or fool.
Ambition, wealth, ease, I renounce the devil
That damns ye here on earth, or I will be --
Mine own mirth, or mine own tormentor, -- So,

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: Here comes intelligence, a Buzz of the Court.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: Rhetias, I sought thee out to tell thee news,
New, excellent new news. Cucolus, Sirrah,
That Gull, that young old Gull, is coming this way.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: And thou art his forerunner?

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: Prithee hear me:
In stead of a fine guarded Page,
We have got him
A Boy, tricked up in neat and handsome
Fashion;
Persuaded him, that it is indeed a Wench;
And he has entertained him, he does follow him,
Carries his sword and buckler, waits on his trencher,
Fills him his Wine, Tobacco, whets his knife,
Lackeys his letters, does what service else
He would employ his man in: being asked,
Why he is so irregular in Courtship?
His answer is, that since great Ladies use
Gentlemen Ushers to go bare before them,
He knows no reason, but he may reduce
The Courtiers to have women wait on them,
And he begins the fashion; he is laughed at
Most complementally. Thou wouldst burst to see him.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: Agelastus, so surnamed for his gravity,
Was a very wise fellow, kept his countenance
All days of his life as demurely, as a Judge that
Pronounceth sentence of death, on a poor Rogue,
For stealing as much bacon, as would serve at a meal
With a Calves head. Yet he smiled once,
And never but once: Thou art no Scholar?

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: I have read Pamphlets dedicated to me:
Dost call him Agelastus? why did he laugh?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
To see an Ass eat Thistles.
Puppy, go study to be a singular Coxcomb. Cuculus is an
Ordinary Ape, but thou art an Ape of an Ape.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: Thou hast a Patent to abuse thy friends:
Look, look, he comes, observe him seriously.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Reach me my sword and buckler.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: They are here, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
How now (Minx) how now? Where is your
duty, your distance?
Let me have service methodically tendered; you are now
One of us. Your curtsy; good: remember that you are
To practise Courtship: was thy father a Piper, sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: A sounder of some such wind instrument forsooth.

sp.speaker: Cucull.
sp.p:
Was he so? hold up thy head; be thou musical
To me, and I will marry thee to a dancer: one
That shall ride on his Foot-cloth, and maintain thee
In thy Muff and Hood.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: That will be fine indeed.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Thou art yet but simple.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: Do ye think so?

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
I have a brain; I have a head-piece;
O my conscience, if I take pains with thee, I should
Raise thy understanding (Girl) to the height of a nurse,
Or a Court-midwife at least, I will make thee big
In time, wench.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: E'en do your pleasure with me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: Noble accomplished Cuculus.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Give me thy fist, Innocent.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Would it were in thy belly, there it is.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: That is well, he is an honest blade, though he be blunt.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Who cares? We can be as blunt as he for his life.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Cuculus, there is within a mile or two, a Sow-pig
Hath sucked a Brach, and now hunts the Deer, the Hare,
Nay, most unnaturally the wild Bore,
As well as any Hound in Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Monstrous Sow-pig! is it true?

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: I will be at charge of a banquet on thee for a sight of her.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Everything takes after the dam that gave it suck:
Where hadst thou thy milk?

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
I? Why, my nurses husband was a most excellent maker
Of Shuttlecocks.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: My nurse was a woman-surgeon.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: And who gave thee pap, Mouse?

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: I never sucked that I remember.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
La now, a Shuttle-cock-maker, all thy brains
are stuck with cork and feather. Cuculus, this learned
Courtier takes after the nurse too, a she-surgeon,
which is in effect a mere matter of colours. Go,
learn to paint and daub complements, it is the next
step to run into a new suit; my Lady Periwinkle here
never sucked; suck thy Master, and bring forth Moon-calves,
Fop, do; This is good Philosophy, Sirs, make
use of it.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: Bless us, what a strange Creature this is?

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: A Gull, an arrant Gull by Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: Corax, the Princes chief Physician;
What business speeds his haste --
Are all things well, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
Cora.
sp.p: So do thy knavery and desperate beggary.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Aha: here is one will tickle the ban-dog.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: You must not go yet.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p:
I will stay in spite of thy teeth. There lies my
gravity:

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Do what thou darest, I stand thee.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Mountebank, Empirics, Quack salvers, Mineralists,
Wizards, Alchemists, cast-Apothecaries, old
Wives and Barbers, are all suppositors to the right
Worshipful Doctor, as I take it.
Some of ye are the head of your Art, and the horns too,
but they come by nature, thou livest single for no other
end, but that thou
fearest to be a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p:
Have at thee; thou affectest railing only for
thy health, thy miseries are so thick and so lasting that
thou hast not one poor denier to bestow on opening a
vein. Wherefore to avoid a Pleurisy, thou wouldst be sure
to prate thyself once a month into a whipping, and
bleed in the breech in stead of the arm.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Have at thee again.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Come.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: There, there, there; O brave Doctor.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: Let them alone.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Thou art in thy Religion an Atheist, in thy
condition a Cur, in thy diet an Epicure, in thy lust a
Goat, in thy sleep a Hog; thou takest upon thee the
habit of a grave Physician, but art indeed an imposturous
Empiric. Physicians are the bodies Cobblers, rather
the Botchers of men's bodies; as the one patches our
tattered clothes, so the other solders our diseased flesh.
Come on.

sp.speaker: Cuc.
sp.p: To it, to it, hold him to it, hold him to it, to it, to it, to it.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p:
The best worth in thee, is the corruption of
thy mind, for that only entitles thee to the dignity of
a louse: a thing bred out of the filth and superfluity of
ill humours: Thou bitest any where; and any man
who defends not himself with the clean linen of secure
honesty; him thou darest not come near. Thou
art Fortunes Idiot, Vertues Bankrupt, Times Dunghill,
Manhoods Scandal, and thine own scourge. Thou
wouldst hang thyself so wretchedly miserable thou
art; but that no man will trust thee with as much money
as will buy a halter: and all thy stock to be sold, is
not worth half as much as may procure it.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; this is flattery, gross flattery.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p:
I have employment for thee, and for ye all,
Tut, these are but good morrows between us.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Are thy bottles full?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Of rich wine, let us all suck together.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Like so many Swine in a trough.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p:
I will shape ye all for a devise before the Prince,
We will try how that can move him.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: He shall fret or laugh.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Must I make one?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Yes, and your feminine Page too.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: Thanks most egregiously.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: I will not slack my part.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Wench, take my buckler.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p:
Come all unto my chamber, the project is cast,
The time only we must attend.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
The melody must agree well, and yield sport,
When such as these are, Knaves and Fools consort.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Enter Amethus, Thamasta and Kala.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Does this show well?

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Not like a Lady of the trim, new crept
Out of the shell of sluttish sweat and labour,
Into the glittering pomp of ease and wantonness,
Embroideries, and all these antic fashions,
That shape a woman monstrous; to transform
Your education, and a Noble birth
Into contempt and laughter. Sister, Sister,
She who derives her blood from Princes, ought
To glorify her greatness by humility.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Then you conclude me proud.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Young Menaphon,
My worthy friend, has loved you long, and truly,
To witness his obedience to your scorn,
Twelve months (wronged Gentleman) he undertook
A voluntary exile. Wherefore (Sister)
In this time of his absence, have you not
Disposed of your affections on some Monarch?
Or sent Ambassadors to some neighbouring King
With fawning protestations of your graces?
Your rare perfections, admirable beauty?
This had been a new piece of modesty,
Would have deserved a Chronicle!

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: You are bitter;
And brother, by your leave, not kindly wise.
My freedom is my births, I am not bound
To fancy your approvements, but my own.
Indeed you are an humble youth, I hear of
Your visits, and your loving commendation
To your hearts Saint, Cleophila, a Virgin
Of a rare excellence: what though she want
A portion to maintain a portly greatness?
Yet it is your gracious sweetness to descend
So low, the meekness of your pity leads ye.
She is your dear friends Sister, a good soul,
An Innocent.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Thamasta.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: I have given
Your Menaphon a welcome home as fits me;
For his sake entertained Parthenophill,
The handsome Stranger, more familiarly
Than (I may fear) becomes me; yet for his part,
I not repent my courtesies, but you --

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: No more, no more; be affable to both:
Time may reclaim your cruelty.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: I pity
The youth, and trust me (brother) love his sadness:
He talks the prettiest stories, he delivers
His tales so gracefully, that I could sit
And listen, nay forget my meals and sleep,
To hear his neat discourses. Menaphon
Was well advised in choosing such a friend,
For pleading his true love.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Now I commend thee,
Thou wilt change at last, I hope.

div2.stage: Enter Menaphon and Eroclea in mans attire.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: I fear I shall.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Have ye surveyed the Garden?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It is a curious,
A pleasantly contrived delight.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Your eye (Sir)
Hath in your travails, often met contents
Of more variety.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Not any (Lady.)

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It were impossible, since your fair presence
Makes every place where it vouchsafes to shine,
More lovely than all other helps of Art
Can equal.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: What you mean by helps of Art,
You know yourself best, be they as they are:
You need none I am sure to set me forth.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It would argue want of manners, more than skill,
Not to praise praise itself

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: For your reward,
Henceforth I will call you Servant.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Excellent Sister.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It is my first step to honour: May I fall
Lower than shame, when I neglect all service
That may confirm this favour.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Are you well, Sir?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Great Princess, I am well, to see a League
Between an humble love, such as my Friends is,
And a commanding virtue, such as yours is,
Are sure restoratives.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: You speak ingeniously.
Brother, be pleased to show the Gallery
To this young stranger, use the time a while,
And we will altogether to the Court.
I will present ye (Sir) unto the Prince.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: You are all composed of fairness, and true bounty.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Come, come, we will wait thee, Sister: this beginning
Doth relish happy process.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: You have blessed me.

div2.stage: Exeunt all but Thamasta and Kala.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Kala, O Kala,

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: We are private, thou art my Closet.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Lock your secrets close then:
I am not to be forced.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Never till now,
Could I be sensible of being traitor
To honour and to shame.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: You are in love.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: I am grown base -- Parthenophill --

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: He is handsome,
Richly endowed; he hath a lovely face,
A winning tongue.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: If ever I must fall,
In him my greatness sinks. Love is a Tyrant
Resisted; whisper in his ear, how gladly
I would steal time, to talk with him one hour;
But do it honourably; prithee Kala
Do not betray me.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Madam, I will make it
Mine own case; he shall think I am in love with him.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: I hope thou art not Kala.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: It is for your sake:
I will tell him so; but Faith I am not, Lady.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Pray use me kindly; let me not too soon
Be lost in my new follies. It is a Fate
That over-rules our wisdoms, whilst we strive
To live most free, we are caught in our own toils.
Diamonds cut Diamonds: they who will prove
To thrive in cunning, must cure love with love.

div2.head: Actus II. Scena I.

sp.speaker: Sophronos.
sp.l: Our Common-wealth is sick: it is more than time
That we should wake the Head thereof, who sleeps
In the dull Lethargy of lost security.
The Commons murmur, and the Nobles grieve,
The Court is now turned Antic, and grows wild,
Whiles all the neighbouring Nations stand at gaze,
And watch fit opportunity, to wreak
Their just conceived fury, on such injuries,
As the late Prince, our living Masters Father,
Committed against Laws of truth or honour.
Intelligence comes flying in on all sides,
Whilst the unsteady multitude presume,
How that you, Aretus, and I, engross
(Out of particular Ambition)
The affairs of government, which I for my part,
Groan under, and am weary of.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: Sophronos,
I am as zealous too of shaking of
My gay State fetters, that I have bethought
Of speedy remedy; and to that end
As I have told ye, have concluded with
Corax, the Princes chief Physician.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: You should have done this sooner, Aretus;
You were his Tutor, and could best discern
His dispositions to inform them rightly.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: Passions of violent nature, by degrees
Are easiliest reclaimed. There is something hid
Of his distemper, which we will now find out.

div2.stage: Enter Corax, Rhetias, Pelias, Cuculus and Grilla.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: You come on just appointment: welcome, Gentlemen,
Have you won Rhetias (Corax?)

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Most sincerely.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
Save ye, Nobilities: do your Lordships
take notice of my Page? It is a fashion of the newest
edition, spick and span new, without example. Do your
honour, Housewife.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: There is a curtsy for you, and a curtsy for you.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p:
It is excellent: we must all follow fashion, and
entertain She-waiters.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: It will be Courtly.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
I think so; I hope the Chronicles will rear
me one day for a head-piece --

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Of Woodcock without brains in it; Barbers
shall wear thee on their Citterns, and Hucksters set
thee out in Ginger-bread.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
Devil take thee: I say nothing to thee now;
canst let me be quiet?

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: You are too perstreperous, Sauce-box.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Good Girl, if we begin to puff once.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p:
Prithee hold thy tongue, the Lords are in the
presence.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Mum, Butterfly.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: O the Prince: stand and keep silence.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
O the Prince: Wench, thou shalt see the
Prince now.

div2.stage: Soft Musicke. Enter Pallador, the Prince, with a Booke in his hand.

sp.speaker: Soph., Aret.
sp.l: Sir; Gracious Sir.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Why all this Company?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: A Book! is this the early exercise
I did prescribe? in stead of following health,
Which all me covet, you pursue your disease.
Where is your great Horse, your Hounds, your set at Tennis,
Your Balloon ball, the practice of your dancing,
Your casting of the sledge, or learning how
To toss a Pike; all changed into a Sonnet?
Pray Sir grant me free liberty to leave
The Court, it does infect me with the sloth
Of sleep and surfeit: In the University
I have employments, which to my profession
Add profit and report: Here I am lost,
And in your wilful dullness held a man
Of neither Art nor honesty: you may
Command my head; pray take it, do; it were better
For me to lose it, than to lose my wits,
And live in Bedlam: you will force me to it,
I am almost mad already.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I believe it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Letters are come from Creete, which do require
A speedy restitution of such ships,
As by your Father were long since detained;
If not; defiance threatened.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: These near parts
Of Syria that adjoin, muster their friends:
And by intelligence we learn for certain,
The Syrian will pretend an ancient interest
Of tribute intermitted.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Through your Land
Your subjects mutter strangely, and imagine
More than they dare speak publicly.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: And yet
They talk but oddly of you.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Hang them Mongrels.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Of me? my subjects talk of me?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Yes, scurvily,
And think worse (Prince.)

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I will borrow patience
A little time to listen to these wrongs,
And from the few of you which are here present,
Conceive the general voice.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: So, now he is nettled.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: By all your loves I charge ye, without fear
Or flattery, to let me know your thoughts,
And how I am interpreted: Speak boldly.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: For my part (Sir) I will be plain, and brief:
I think you are of Nature mild and easy,
Not willingly provoked, but withal head-strong
In any passion that misleads your Judgment.
I think you too indulgent to such motions,
As spring out of your own affections,
Too old to be reformed, and yet too young
To take fit counsel from yourself, of what
Is most amiss.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: So -- Tutor, your conceit?

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: I think you dote (with pardon let me speak it)
Too much upon your pleasures, and these pleasures
Are so wrapped up in self-love that you covet
No other change of fortune: would be still
What your birth makes you, but are loath to toil
In such affairs of State as break your sleeps.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: I think you would be by the world, reputed
A man in every point complete, but are
In manners and effect indeed a child,
A boy, a very boy.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: May it please your Grace,
I think you do contain within yourself
The great Elixir, soul and quintessence
Of all divine perfections: are the glory
Of mankind, and the only strict example
For earthly Monarchies to square out their lives by:
Times miracle, Fames pride, in Knowledge, Wit,
Sweetness, Discourse, Arms, Arts --

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: You are a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
But not of the ancient fashion, if it like your
Highness. It is I; I, that am the credit of the Court,
Noble Prince: and if thou wouldst by Proclamation or
Patent, create me Overseer of all the Tailors in thy Dominions;
then, then the golden days should appear
again; bread should be cheaper; fools should have
more wit; knaves more honesty; and beggars more
money.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: I think now --

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Peace you Squall.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: You have not spoken yet.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Hang him, he will nothing but rail.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: Most abominable: out upon him.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Away Cuculus; follow the Lords.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Close Page, close.

div2.stage: They all fall backe, and steale out. Manet Prince and Rhetias.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: You are somewhat long a thinking.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: I do not think at all.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Am I not worthy of your thought?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
My pity you are --
But not my reprehension.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Pity?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Yes, for I pity such to whom I owe service,
who exchange their happiness for a misery.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Is it a misery to be a Prince?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Princes who forget their sovereignty, and
yield to affected passion, are weary of command. You
had a Father, Sir.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Your Sovereign whiles he lived. But what of
him?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Nothing. I only dared to name him; that is
all.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
I charge thee by the duty that thou owest us
be plain in what thou meanest to speak there is something
that we must know: be free, our ears are open.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
O Sir, I had rather hold a Wolf by the ears,
than stroke a Lion, the greatest danger is the last.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: This is mere trifling -- Ha? are all stolen hence?
We are alone: Thou hast an honest look,
Thou hast a tongue, I hope, that is not oiled
With flattery. Be open, though it is true,
That in my younger days I oft have heard
Agenors name, my Father, more traduced,
Than I could then observe; yet I protest,
I never had a friend, a certain friend,
That would inform me thoroughly of such errors,
As oftentimes are incident to Princes.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
All this may be. I have seen a man so curious
in feeling of the edge of a keen knife, that he has cut his
fingers. My flesh is not of proof against the metal I
am to handle; the one is tenderer than the other.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I see then I must court thee. Take the word
Of a just Prince for anything thou speakest.
I have more than a Pardon, thanks and love.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
I will remember you of an old Tale that something
concerns you. Meleander, the great (but unfortunate
Statesman, was by your Father treated with for a Match
between you and his eldest daughter, the Lady Eroclea.
You were both near of an age. I presume you remember
a Contract, and cannot forget Her.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: She was a lovely beauty: Prithee forward.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
To Court was Eroclea brought, was courted by
your Father, not for Prince Palador, as it followed, but
to be made a prey to some less noble design. --
With your favour I have forgot the rest.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Good call it back again into thy memory,
Else losing the remainder, I am lost too.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
You charm me. In brief, a Rape, by some
bad Agents, was attempted; by the Lord Meleander
her father rescued, she conveyed away, Meleander accused
of treason, his Land seized, he himself distracted and
confined to the Castle where he yet lives. What had
ensued was doubtful. But your Father shortly after died.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: But what became of fair Eroclea?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: She never since was heard of.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: No hope lives then
Of ever, ever seeing her again.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Sir, I fear I should anger ye. There was, as I
said, an old Tale; I have now a new one, which may perhaps
season the first with a more delightful relish.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I am prepared to hear, say what you please.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
My Lord Meleander falling, on whose favour
my fortunes relied, I furnished myself for travail, and
bent my course to Athens, where a pretty accident after
a while came to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: My ear is open to thee.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
A young Lady contracted to a noble Gentleman,
as the Lady we last mentioned, and your Highness
were, being hindered by their jarring Parents, stole from
her home, and was conveyed like a Ship-boy in a Merchant,
from the Country where she lived, into Corinth
first, and afterwards to Athens; where in much solitariness
she lived like a Youth almost two years, courted
by all for acquaintance, but friend to none by familiarity.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: In habit of a man?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
A handsome young man, till within these three
months, or less, her sweet hearty Father dying some
year before, or more, she had notice of it, and with
much joy returned home, and as report voiced it, at Athens
enjoyed her happiness: she was long an exile:
For now Noble Sir, if you did love the Lady Eroclea,
why may not such safety and fate direct her, as directed
the other? it is not impossible.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: If I did love her, Rhetias: yes I did.
Give me thy hand: As thou didst serve Meleander,
And art still true to these, henceforth serve me.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: My duty and my obedience are my surety,
But I have been too bold.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Forget the sadder story of my Father,
And only Rhetias, learn to read me well,
For I must ever thank thee; thou hast unlocked
A tongue was vowed to silence, for requital
Open my bosom, Rhetias.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: What is your meaning?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: To tie thee to an oath of secrecy --
Unloose the buttons, man, thou dost it faintly,
What findest thou there?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: A picture in a Tablet.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Look well upon it.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: I do -- yes -- let me observe it --
It is hers, the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Whose!

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: Erocleas.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Hers that was once Eroclea: for her sake
Have I advanced Sophronos to the Helm
Of government; for her sake will restore
Meleanders Honours to him; will for her sake
Beg friendship from thee, Rhetias. O be faithful,
And let no politic Lord work from thy bosom
My griefs: I know thou wert put on to sift me:
But be not too secure.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: I am your Creature.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Continue still thy discontented fashion:
Humour the Lords, as they would humour me;
I will not live in thy debt. --
We are discovered.

div2.stage: Enter Amethus, Menaphon, Thamasta, Kala, Eroclea, as before.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Honour and health still wait upon the Prince.
Sir, I am bold with favour to present
Unto your Highness, Menaphon my friend,
Returned from travail.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: Humbly on my knees
I kiss your gracious hand.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: It is our duty
To love the virtuous.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: If my prayers or service
Hold -- any value, they are vowed yours ever.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
I have a fist for thee too (Stripling) thou art started
up prettily since I saw thee. Hast learned any wit abroad?
Canst tell news, and swear lies with a grace like a true
Traveller? What new Owzle's this?

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Your Highness shall do right to your own judgment,
In taking more than common notice of
This stranger, an Athenian, named Parthenophill.
One, (whom if mine opinion do not sooth me
Too grossly) for the fashion of his mind,
Deserves a dear respect.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Your commendations,
Sweet Cousin, speaks him Nobly.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: All the powers
That sentinel just Thrones, double these guards
About your sacred Excellence.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: What fortune led him to Cyprus!

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: My persuasions won him.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: And if your Highness please to hear the entrance
Into their first acquaintance, you will say --

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: It was the newest, sweetest, prettiest accident,
That ever delighted your attention.
I can discourse it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Some other time.
How is he called?

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Parthenophill.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Parthenophill?
We shall sort time to take more notice of him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: His wonted melancholy still pursues him.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: I told you so.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: You must not wonder at it.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: I do not, Lady.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Shall we to the Castle?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: We will attend ye both.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
All three -- I will go too. Hark in thine ear,
Gallant: I will keep the old mad man in chat, whilst thou
gabblest to the girl: my thumb is upon my lips, not a
word.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.p:
I need not fear thee, Rhetias. -- Sister, soon
Expect us: this day we will range the City.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Well, soon I shall expect ye. -- Kala?

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Trust me.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Troop on -- Love, love, what a wonder thou
art?

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: May I not be offensive, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Your pleasure; yet pray be brief.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Then briefly, good, resolve me:
Have you a Mistress, or a Wife?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: I have neither.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Nor did you ever love in earnest any
Fair Lady, whom you wished to make your own?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Not any truly.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: What your friends or means are
I will not be inquisitive to know,
Nor do I care to hope for. But admit
A dower were thrown down before your choice,
Of Beauty, Noble birth, and sincere affection,
How gladly would you entertain it? (Young man)
I do not tempt you idly.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: I shall thank you,
When my unsettled thoughts can make me sensible
Of what it is to be happy: for the present
I am your debtor: and fair Gentlewoman,
Pray give me leave as yet to study ignorance,
For my weak brains conceive not what concern me.
-- Another time. --

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Do I break off your Parley
That you are parting? Sure my woman loves you.
Can she speak well, Parthenophill?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Yes, Madam:
Discreetly chaste she can: she hath much won
On my belief, and in few words, but pithy,
Much moved my thankfulness. You are her Lady,
Your goodness aims (I know) at her preferment:
Therefore I may be bold to make confession
Of truth, if ever I desire to thrive
In woman's favour. Kala is the first
Whom my ambition shall bend to.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Indeed.
But say a Nobler love should interpose?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Where real worth, and constancy first settle
A hearty truth, there greatness cannot shake it,
Nor shall it mine: yet I am but an Infant
In that construction, which must give clear light
To Kala's merit: riper hours hereafter
Must learn me how to grow rich in deserts.
Madam, my duty waits on you.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Come hither.
If ever henceforth I desire to thrive
In woman's favours, Kala is the first
Whom my ambition shall bend to -- it was so.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.l: These very words he spake.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: These very words
Curse thee, unfaithful creature, to thy grave:
Thou wouldst him for thyself?

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: You said I should.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: My name was never mentioned!

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Madam, no:
We were not come to that.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Not come to that?
Art thou a Rival fit to cross my Fate?
Now poverty and a dishonest fame,
The waiting-womans wages, be thy payment.
False, faithless, wanton beast, I will spoil your carriage;
There is not a Page, a Groom, nay, not a Citizen
That shall be cast upon ye. Kala,
I will keep thee in my service all thy life time,
Without hope of a husband or a suitor.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: I have not verily deserved this cruelty.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Parthenophill shall know, if he respect
My birth, the danger of a fond neglect.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Are you so quick? Well, I may chance to cross
Your peevishness. Now though I never meant
The young man for myself; yet if he love me,
I will have him, or I will run away with him,
And let her do her worst then: what, we are all
But flesh and blood; the same thing that will do
My Lady good, will please her woman too.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Tread softly (Trollio) my Father sleeps still.

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p:
Aye forsooth: but he sleeps like a Hare with his
eyes open, and that is no good sign.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Sure thou art weary of this sullen living,
But I am not; for I take more content
In my obedience here, than all delights
The time presents elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Dost hear that groan?

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p:
Hear it? I shudder, it was a strong blast, young
Mistress, able to root up heart, liver, lungs and all.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: My much-wronged Father: let me view his face.

div2.stage: Drawes the Arras, Meleander discouered in a chaire sleeping.

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p:
Lady Mistress, shall I fetch a Barber to steal
away his rough beard, whiles he sleeps in his naps? He
never looks in a glass, and it is high time on conscience
for him to be trimmed, has not been under the Shavers
hand almost these four years.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Peace, fool.

sp.speaker: Trol.
sp.p:
I could clip the old Ruffian, there is hair enough
to stuff all the great Codpieces in Switzerland. He begins
to stir, he stirs. Bless us how his eyes roll. A
good year keep your
Lordship in your right wits, I
beseech ye.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Cleophila?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Sir, I am here, how do ye Sir?

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p:
Sir, is your stomach up yet? get some warm
porridge in your belly, it is a very good settle-brain.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: The Raven croaked, and hollow shrieks of Owls
Sung Dirges at her funeral; I laughed
The whiles: for it was no boot to weep. The Girl
Was fresh and full of youth: but, O the cunning
Of Tyrants that look big, their very frowns
Doom poor souls guilty, ere their cause be heard.
Good. What art thou, and thou?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I am Cleophila,
Your woeful daughter.

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p: I am Trollia your honest implement.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I know ye both. alas, why do ye use me thus!
Thy Sister, my Eroclea, was so gentle,
That Turtles in their Down do feed more gall,
Than her spleen mixed with: yet when winds and storm
Drive dirt and dust on banks of spotless snow,
The purest whiteness is no such defence
Against the sullying foulness of that fury.
So raved Agenor, that great man, mischief
Against the Girl -- it was a politic trick,
We were too old in Honour. -- I am lean
And fallen away extremely; most assuredly
I have not dined these three days.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Will you now, Sir?

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p:
I beseech ye heartily Sir. I feele a horrible
puking myself.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Am I stark mad?

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p:
No, no, you are but a little staring. -- there is
difference between staring and stark mad. You are
but whimseyed, yet crocheted, conundrumed, or so.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Here is all my care: and I do often sigh
For thee, Cleophyla: we are secluded
From all good people. But take heed, Amethus
Was son to Doryla, Agenors Sister.
There is some ill blood about him, if the Surgeon
Have not been very skilful to let all out.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I am (alas) too grieved to think of love,
That must concern me least.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Sirrah, be wise, be wise.

div2.stage: Enter Amethus, Menaphon, Eroclea (as before) and Rhetias.

sp.speaker: Troll.
sp.p:
Who I? I will be monstrous and wise immediately.
Welcome, Gentlemen, the more the merrier, I will
lay the cloth, and set the stools in a readiness, for I see
here is some hope of dinner now.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: My Lord Meleander, Menaphon your Kinsman
Newly returned from travail, comes to tender
His duty to ye: to you his love, fair Mistress.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I would I could as easily remove
Sadness from your remembrance, Sir, as study
To do you faithful service -- my dear Cousin,
All best of comforts bless your sweet obedience.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: One chief of them (worthy Cousin) lives
In you, and your well-doing.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: This young stranger
Will well deserve your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: For my friends sake,
Lady pray give him welcome.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: He has met it, if sorrows can look kindly.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: You much honour me.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
How he eyes the company: sure my passion will
betray my weakness -- O my Master, my Noble
Master, do not forget me, I am still the humblest, and
the most faithful in heart of those that serve you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
There is wormwood in that laughter, it is the
usher to a violent extremity.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I am a weak old man. All these are come
To jeer my ripe calamities.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: Good Uncle!

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: But I will out-stare ye all, fools, desperate fools,
You are cheated, grossly cheated, range, range on,
And roll about the world to gather moss,
The moss of honour, gay reports, gay clothes,
Gay wives, huge empty buildings, whose proud roofs,
Shall with their pinnacles, even reach the stars.
Ye work and work like Moles, blind in the paths,
That are bored through the crannies of the earth,
To charge your hungry souls with such full surfeits,
As being gorged once, make ye lean with plenty.
And when ye have skimmed the vomit of your riots,
You arefat in no felicity but folly,
Then your last sleeps seize on ye. Then the troops
Of worms crawl round, and, feast, good cheer, rich fare,
Dainty delicious -- here is Cleophyla:
All the poor stock of my remaining thrift;
You, you, the Princes Cousin: how do ye like her?
(Amethus) how do ye like her?

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: My intents are just and honourable.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Sir, believe him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Take her. -- we two must part, go to him, do.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: This sight is full of horror.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: This is sense yet in this distraction.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: In this Jewel I have given away,
All what I can call mine. When I am dead,
Save charge; let me be buried in a nook.
No guns, no pompous whining: these are fooleries.
If whiles we live, we stalk about the streets,
Jostled by Carmen, Foot-posts, and fine Apes,
In silken coats, unminded, and scarce thought of
It is not comely to be haled to the earth,
Like high fed lades upon a Tilting-day,
In antique trappings: scorn to useless tears.
Eroclea was not coffined so: she perished,
And no eye dropped save mine, and I am childish.
I talk like one that dotes; laugh at me, Rhetias,
Or rail at me: they will not give me meat:
They have starved me: but I will henceforth be mine own Cook.
Good morrow: it is too early for my cares
To revel. I will break my heart a little,
And tell ye more hereafter. Pray be merry.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.l: I will follow him. My Lord Amethus, use your time
Respectively. Few words to purpose soonest prevail:
Study no long Orations; be plain and short,
I will follow him.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Cleophyla, although these blacker clouds
Of sadness, thicken and make dark the sky
Of thy fair eyes, yet give me leave to follow
The stream of my affections: they are pure,
Without all mixture of unnoble thoughts.
Can you be ever mine?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I am so low
In mine own fortunes, and my Fathers woes,
That I want words to tell ye, you deserve
A worthier choice.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: But give me leave to hope.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: My friend is serious.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Sir, this for answer: If I ever thrive
In an earthly happiness, the next
To my good Fathers wished recovery,
Must be my thankfulness to your great merit;
Which I dare promise for the present time:
You cannot urge more from me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Ho, Cleophyla?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: This Gentleman is moved.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Your eyes, Parthenophill,
Are guilty of some passion.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Friend, what ails thee?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: All is not well within me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Meleander
sp.l: Cleophyla?

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Sweet Maid, forget me not; we now must part.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Still you shall have my prayer.

sp.speaker: Ame.
sp.l: Still you my truth.

div2.head: Actus III. Scena I.
div2.stage: Enter Cuculus and Grilla, Cuculus in a blacke veluet Cap, and a white Feather, with a paper in his hand.

sp.speaker: Cuculus.
sp.p:
Do not I look freshly, and like a Youth of the
Trim?

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p:
As rare an old Youth as ever walked
cross-gartered.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
Here are my Mistresses mustered in white and
black. Kala the Waiting-woman. I will first begin at
the soot: stand thou for Kala.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: I stand for Kala, do your best and your worst.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
I must look big, and care little or nothing
for her, because she is a creature that stands at livery.
Thus I talk wisely, and to no purpose. Wench, as it is
not fit that thou shouldst be either fair or honest; so
considering thy service, thou art as thou art, and so are
thy betters, let them be what they can be. Thus in
despite and defiance of all thy good parts, if I cannot endure
thy baseness, it is more out of thy courtesy, than my
deserving, and so I expect thy answer.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: I must confess --

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Well said.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: You are --

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: That is true too.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: To speak you right, a very scurvy fellow. --

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: Away, away, dost think so?

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: A very foul mouthed, and misshapen Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.l: I will never believe it by this hand.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.l: A Maggot, most unworthy to creep in --
-- To the least wrinkle of a Gentlewoman's
(What do ye call) good conceit, or so, or what
You will else. -- Were you not refined by Courtship
And education, which in my blear eyes
Makes you appear as sweet as any nosegay,
Or savoury cod of Musk new fallen from the Cat.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
This shall serve well enough for the Waiting-woman.
My next Mistress is Cleophyla, the old mad-man's
daughter: I must come to her in whining tune, sigh,
wipe mine eyes, fold my Arms, and blubber out my
speech as thus: Even as a Kennel of Hounds (sweet
Lady) cannot catch a Hare, when they are full paunched
on the Carrion of a dead Horse: so, even so the gorge of
my affections being full crammed with the garboils of
your condolements, doth tickle me with the prick (as it
were) about me, and fellow-feeling of howling outright.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: This will do it, if we will hear.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
Thou seest I am crying ripe, I am such another
tender-hearted fool.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p:
Even as the snuff of a candle that is burnt in
the socket, goes out, and leaves a strong perfume behind
it; or as a piece of toasted cheese next the heart in a
morning is a restorative for a sweet breath: so even so
the odoriferous savour of your love doth perfume my
heart, (Hey ho) with the pure sent of an intolerable
content, and not to be endured.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
By this hand it is excellent. Have at thee last
of all: for the Princess Thamasta, she that is my Mistress
indeed, she is abominably proud. A Lady of a damnable,
high, turbulent, and generous spirit. But I have a
loud-mouthed Cannon of mine own to batter her, and
a penned speech of purpose; observe it.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: Thus I walk by, hear and mind you not.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.l: Though haughty as the Devil or his Dam,
Thou dost appear, great Mistress: yet I am
Like to an ugly firework, and can mount
Above the Region of thy sweet Account.
Wert thou the Moon herself, yet having seen thee,
Behold the man ordained to move within thee.
-- Look to yourself, Housewife; answer me
In strong Lines you are best.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.l: Keep off, poor fool, my beams will strike thee blind:
Else if thou touch me, touch me but behind.
In Palaces, such as pass in before,
Must be great Princes; for at the back door
Tatter-demallains wait, who know not how
To get admittance: such a one -- art Thou.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p: 'sfoot, this is downright roaring.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p:
I know how to present a big Lady in her own
cue. But pray in earnest, are you in love with all these?

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
Pish, I have not a rag of love about me. It is
only a foolish humour I am possessed with, to be surnamed
the Conqueror. I will court anything; be in love
with nothing, nor no -- thing.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p: A rare man you are, I protest.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.p:
Yes, I know I am a rare man, and I ever held
myself so.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.l: In amorous contemplation on my life;
Courting his Page by Helicon.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.l: It is false.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.l: A gross untruth; I will justify it, Sir,
At any time, place, weapon.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.l: Marry shall she.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p:
No quarrels, good ye Whisk. Lay by your
Trumperies, and fall to your practice. Instructions are
ready for you all. Pelias is your Leader, follow him. Get
credit now or never. Vanish, Doodles, vanish.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.l: For the Device.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: The same, get ye gone, and make no bawling.
To waste my time thus Drone-like in the Court,
And lose so many hours, as my studies
Have horded up, is to be like a man
That creeps both on his hands and knees, to climb
A mountains top, where when he is ascended,
One careless slip down, tumbles him again
Into the bottom whence he first began.
I need no Princes favour: Princes need
My Art. Then Corax, be no more a Gull,
The best of them cannot fool thee, nay, they shall not.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: We find him timely now, let us learn the cause.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: It is fit we should -- Sir, we approve you learned,
And since your skill can best discern the humours
That are predominant, in bodies subject
To alteration: tell us (pray) what devil
This Melancholy is, which can transform
Men into Monsters.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: You are yourself a Scholar,
And quick of apprehension: Melancholy
Is not as you conceive. Indisposition
Of body, but the minds disease. So Ecstasy,
Fantastic Dotage, Madness, Frenzy, Rupture,
Of mere imagination differ partly Vid. Democrit. Junior.
From Melancholy, which is briefly this,
A mere commotion of the mind, over-charged
With fear and sorrow; first begot in the brain,
The Seat of Reason, and from thence derived
As suddenly into the Heart, the Seat
Of our Affection.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: There are sundry kinds
Of this disturbance.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Infinite, it were
More easy to conjecture every hour
We have to live, than reckon up the kinds,
Or causes of this anguish of the mind.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Thus you conclude, that as the cause is doubtful,
The cure must be impossible; and then
Our Prince (poor Gentleman) is lost for ever,
As well unto himself, as to his subjects.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: My Lord, you are too quick; thus much I dare
Promise, and do, ere many minutes pass,
I will discover whence his sadness is,
Or undergo the censure of my ignorance.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: You are a Noble Scholar.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: For reward,
You shall make your own demand.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: May I be sure?

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: We both will pledge our truth.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: It is soon performed,
That I may be discharged from my attendance
At Court, and never more be sent for after:
Or if I be, may Rats gnaw all my books,
If I get home once, and come here again,
Though my neck stretch a halter for it, I care not.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Come, come, you shall not fear it.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: I will acquaint ye
With what is to be done, and you shall fashion it.

div2.stage: Exeunt omnes. Enter Kala and Eroclea, as before.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: My Lady does expect ye, thinks all time
Too slow till you come to her: wherefore young man,
If you intend to love me, and me only,
Before we part, without more circumstance
Let us betroth ourselves.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: I dare not wrong ye;
You are too violent.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Wrong me no more
Than I wrong you: be mine, and I am yours:
I cannot stand on points.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Then to resolve
All further hopes, you never can be mine,
Must not, (and pardon though I say) you shall not.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: The thing is sure a Gelding -- Shall not? well,
You are best to prate unto my Lady now,
What proffer I have made.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Never, I vow.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Do, do, it is but a kind heart of mine own,
And ill luck can undo me. -- Be refused?
Of scurvy. -- Pray walk on, I will overtake ye.
What a green sickness-liuered Boy is this!

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: My Maiden-head will shortly grow so stale,
That it will be mouldy: but I will mar her market.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Parthenophill past the way; prithee Kala
Direct me to him.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Yes, I can direct ye:
But you (Sir) must forbear.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Forbear!

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: I said so.
Your bounty has engaged my truth; receive
A secret, that will, as you are a man,
Startle your Reason: it is but mere respect
Of what I owe to thankfulness. (Dear Sir)
The Stranger whom your courtesy received
For Friend, is made your Rival.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Rival, Kala.
Take heed, thou art too credulous.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: My Lady
Dotes on him: I will place you in a room,
Where, though you cannot hear, yet you shall see
Such passages as will confirm the truth
Of my intelligence.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It will make me mad.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Yes, yes: it makes me mad too, that a Gentleman
So excellently sweet, so liberal,
So kind, so proper, should be so betrayed
By a young smooth-chinned straggler: but for loves sake
Bear all with manly courage. -- Not a word,
I am undone then.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: That were too much pity:
Honest, most honest Kala; it is thy care,
Thy serviceable care.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.l: You have even spoken all can be said or thought.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I will reward thee:
But as for him, ungentle Boy, I will whip
His falsehood with a vengeance.--

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: O speak little.
Walk up these stairs, and take this key, it opens
A Chamber door, where at that window yonder,
You may see all their courtship.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I am silent.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: As little noise as may be, I beseech ye;
There is a back-stair to convey ye forth
Unseen or unsuspected. -- He that cheats
A Waiting-woman of a free good turn
She longs for, must expect a shrewd revenge.
Sheep-spirited Boy, although he had not married me,
He might have proffered kindness in a corner,
And never have been the worse for it. They are come;
On goes my set of Faces most demurely.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Forbear the room.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.p:
Whosoever requires access to me, deny him
entrance till I call thee, and wait without.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: I shall. Sweet Venus, turn his courage to a
Snow-ball, I heartily beseech it.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: I expose
The Honour of my Birth, my Fame, my Youth,
To hazard of much hard construction,
In seeking an adventure of a parley
So private with a Stranger; if your thoughts
Censure me not with mercy, you may soon
Conceive, I have laid by that modesty,
Which should preserve a virtuous name unstained.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Lady, to shorten long excuses; time
And safe experience have so thoroughly armed
My apprehension, with a real taste
Of your most Noble nature, that to question
The least part of your bounties, or that freedom
Which Heaven hath with a plenty made you rich in,
Would argue me uncivil, which is more,
Base-bred, and which is most of all, unthankful.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: The constant Lodestone, and the Steel are found
In several Mines: yet is there such a league
Between these Minerals, as if one Vein
Of earth had nourished both. The gentle Myrtle
Is not engraft upon an Olives stock:
Yet nature hath between them locked a secret
Of Sympathy, that being planted near,
They will both in their branches, and their roots
Embrace each other; twines of Ivy round
The well grown Oak; the Vine doth court the Elm;
Yet these are different Plants. Parthenophill,
Consider this aright, then these sleight creatures,
Will fortify the reasons I should frame
For that ungrounded (as thou thinkest) affection,
Which is submitted to a strangers pity.
True love may blush, when shame repents too late,
But in all actions, Nature yields to Fate.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Great Lady, it were a dullness must exceed
The grossest and most sottish kind of ignorance,
Not to be sensible of your intents:
I clearly understand them. Yet so much
The difference between that height and lowness,
Which doth distinguish our unequal fortunes,
Dissuades me from ambition; that I am
Humbler in my desires, than Loves own power
Can any way raise up

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: I am a Princess,
And know no law of slavery, to sue,
Yet be denied?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: I am so much a subject
To every law of Noble honesty,
That to transgress the vows of perfect friendship,
I hold a sacrilege as foul, and cursed,
As if some holy Temple had been robbed,
And I the thief.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Thou art unwise, young man,
To enrage a Lioness.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: It were unjust
To falsify a faith, and ever after
Disrobed of that fair ornament, live naked,
A scorn to time and truth.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Remember well who I am, and what thou art.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: That remembrance
Prompts me to worthy duty, O great Lady.
If some few days have tempted your free heart,
To cast away affection on a stranger:
If that affection have so overswayed
Your Judgment, that it in a manner hath
Declined your sovereignty of birth and spirit:
How can ye turn your eyes off from that glass,
Wherein you may new Trim, and settle right
A memorable name?

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: The Youth is idle.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Days, months and years are past, since Menaphon
Hath loved and served you truly: Menaphon;
A man of no large distance in his blood,
From yours; in qualities desertful, graced
With Youth, Experience; every happy gift
That can by nature, or by Education
Improve a Gentleman: for him (great Lady)
Let me prevail, that you will yet at last,
Unlock the bounty, which your love and care
Have wisely treasured up, to enrich his life.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Thou hast a moving eloquence; Parthenophill,
Parthenophill, in vain we strive to cross
The destiny that guides us. My great heart
Is stooped so much beneath that wonted pride
That first disguised it, that I now prefer
A miserable life with thee, before
All other earthly comforts.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Menaphon, by me, repeats the selfsame words to you:
You are too cruel, if you can distrust
His truth, or my report.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Go where thou wilt,
I will be an exile with thee, I will learn
To bear all change of fortunes.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: For my friend, I plead with grounds of reason.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: For thy love,
Hard-hearted youth, I here renounce all thoughts
Of other hopes, of other entertainments, --

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Stay, as you honour Virtue.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: When the proffers of other greatness --

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: When entreats of friends; --

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: I will ease your grief.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Respect of kindred;

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Pray give me hearing.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Loss of Fame;

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: I crave but some few minutes.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Shall infringe my vows, let Heaven --

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: My love speak to ye; hear then, go on.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Thy love, why, it is a Charm to stop a vow
In its most violent course.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Cupid has broke
His Arrows here; and like a child unarmed,
Comes to make sport between us with no weapon,
But feathers stolen from his mothers Doves.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: This is mere trifling.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Lady, take a secret.
I am as you are, in a lower rank
Else of the self same sex, a maid, a virgin.
And now to use your own words, if your thoughts
Censure me not with mercy, you may soon
Conceive, I have laid by that modesty,
Which should preserve a virtuous name unstained.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Are you not mankind then?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: When you shall read
The story of my sorrows, with the change
Of my misfortunes, in a letter printed
From my unforged relation; I believe
You will not think the shedding of one tear,
A prodigality that misbecomes
Your pity and my fortune.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Pray conceal the errors of my passions.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Would I had
Much more of honour (as for life I value it not)
To venture on your secrecy.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: It will be
A hard task for my Reason, to relinquish
The affection which was once devoted thine,
I shall a while repute thee still the youth
I loved so dearly.

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: You shall find me ever, your ready faithful servant.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: O the powers
Who do direct our hearts, laugh at our follies!
We must not part yet.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Let not my unworthiness alter your good opinion.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: I shall henceforth
Be jealous of thy company with any;
My fears are strong and many.

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Did your Ladyship call me?

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Kala.
sp.l: Your servant Menaphon desires admittance.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: With your leave, great Mistress! I come --
So private: is this well, Parthenophill?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: Sir, Noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: You are unkind and treacherous.
This it is to trust a straggler.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Prithee servant.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I dare not question you, you are my Mistress;
My Princes nearest Kinswoman, but he --

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Come, you are angry.

sp.speaker: Mena.
sp.l: Henceforth I will bury
Unmanly passion in perpetual silence.
I will court mine own distraction, dote on folly,
Creep to the mirth and madness of the age,
Rather than be so slaved again to woman,
Which in her best of constancy is steadiest
In change and scorn.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: How dare ye talk to me thus?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Dare? Were you not own Sister to my friend,
Sister to my Amethus; I would hurl ye
As far off from mine eyes, as from my heart;
For I would never more look on ye. Take
Your Jewel to ye. And Youth, keep under wing,
Or -- Boy -- Boy.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: If commands be of no force,
Let me entreat thee, Menaphon.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It is naught, fie, fie, Parthenophill, have I deserved
To be thus used?

sp.speaker: Eroc.
sp.l: I do protest --

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: You shall not,
Henceforth I will be free, and hate my bondage.

sp.speaker: Amet.
sp.l: Away, away to Court, the Prince is pleased
To see a Mask tonight, we must attend him:
It is near upon the time. -- How thrives your suit?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: The Judge, your Sister, will decide it shortly.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Parthenophill, I will not trust you from me.

div2.stage: Enter Prince, Aretas, Corax (with a Paper-plot) seruants with torches.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Lights and attendance, I will show your highness,
A trifle of mine own brain. If you can,
Imagine you were now in the University,
You will take it well enough, a Scholars fancy,
A quab. It is nothing else a very quab.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: We will observe it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Yes, and grace it too Sir.
For Corax else is humorous and testy.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: By any means, men singular in Art,
have always some odd whimsy more than usual.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: The name of this conceit.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Sir, it is called the Mask of Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Aret.
sp.l: We must look for nothing but sadness, here then.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Madness rather
In several changes: Melancholy is
The Root as well of every Apish Frenzy,
Laughter and mirth, as dullness. Pray my Lord
Hold and observe the plot, it is there expressed
In kind, what shall be now expressed in action.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: No interpretation, take your places quickly.
Nay, nay, leave ceremony: sound to the entrance.

div2.stage: Florish. Enter Rhetias, his face whited, blacke shag haire, long nailes, a piece of raw meate.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Bow, Bow, wow, wow; the Moon is eclipsed,
I will to the Church-yard and sup: Since I turned Wolf,
I bark and howl, and dig up graves, I will never have
the Sun shine again, it is midnight, deep dark midnight,
get a prey, and fall too, I have catched thee now.
Arre.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: This kind is called, Lycanthropia, Sir,
When men conceive themselves Wolves.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Here I find it.

div2.stage: Enter Pelias. A Crowne of feathers on, Antickly rich.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p:
I will hang them all, and burn my wife: was I not an
Emperor; my hand was kissed, and Ladies lay down before
me. In triumph did I ride with my Nobles about
me, till the mad-dog bit me, I fell, and I fell, and I fell.
It shall be treason by Statute for any man to name water,
or wash his hands throughout all my Dominions;
break all the looking-glasses, I will not see my horns;
my wife Cuckolds me, she is a whore, a whore, a whore,
a whore.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Hydrophobia term you this?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: And men possessed so, shun all sight of water:
Sometimes, if mixed with jealousy, it renders them
Incurable, and oftentimes brings death.

div2.stage: Enter Philosopher in blacke rags, a copper chaine on, an old Gowne halfe off, and Booke.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
Philosophers dwell in the Moon Speculation and
Theory girdle the world about like a wall. Ignorance
like an Atheist, must be damned in the pit. I am very,
very poor, and poverty is the physic for the soul: my
opinions are pure and perfect. Envy is a monster, and
I defy the beast.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Delirium this is called, which is mere dotage,
Sprung from Ambition first, and singularity,
Self love,and blind opinion of true merit.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I not dislike the course.

div2.stage: Enter Grilla in a rich Gowne, great Vardingale, great Ruffe, Muffe, Fan, and Coxcombe on her head.

sp.speaker: Grill.
sp.p:
Yes forsooth, and no forsooth, is not this fine,
I pray, your blessing Gaffer, here, here, here did he give
me a shough, and cut off his tail: buss, buss Nuncle, and
there is a pum for Daddy.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: You find this noted there, Phrenitis.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Pride is the ground of it;
It reigns most in women.

div2.stage: Enter Cuculus like a Bedlam singing.

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.l: They that will learn to drink a health in Hell,
Must learn on earth to take Tobacco well,
To take Tobacco well, to take Tobacco well:
For in Hell they drink nor Wine, nor Ale, nor Beer,
But fire, and smoke, and stench, as we do hear

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: I will soop thee up

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: Thou wouldst straight to execution.

sp.speaker: Gril.
sp.p: Fool, Fool, Fool, catch me if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Philos.
sp.p: Expel him the house, it is a Dunce.

sp.speaker: Cul.
sp.l: Hark, did ye not hear a rumbling,
The Gobblings are now a tumbling:
I will tear them,, I will sear them,
Now, now, now, my brains are a Jumbling, --
Bounce, the gun is off.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: You name this here, Hypocondriacal.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Which is a windy flattuous humour stuffing
The head, and thence derived to the animal parts
To be too over-curious, loss of goods,
Or friends, excess of fear, or sorrows cause it.

div2.stage: Enter a Sea-nimph big-bellied, singing and dancing.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Good your Honours,
Pray your Worships,
Dear your Beauties,

sp.speaker: Cucul.
sp.l: Hang thee.
To lash your sides,
To tame your hides,
To scourge your prides,
And bang thee.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Were pretty and dainty, and I will begin,
See how they do Jeer me, deride me, and grin:
Come sport me, come court me, your Topsail advance,
And let us conclude our delights in a Dance.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Dance, a Dance, a Dance.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: This is the Wanton Melancholy; women
With child possessed with this strange fury often,
Have danced three days together without ceasing.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: It is very strange: but Heaven is full of miracles.

div2.stage: The Dance: -- Which ended, they all run out in couples.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: We are thy debtor (Corax) for the gift
Of this invention: but the plot deceives us
What means this empty space.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: One kind of Melancholy
Is only left untouched; it was not in Art
To personate the shadow of that Fancy.
It is named love-melancholy. As for instance,
Admit this stranger here (Young man, stand forth)
Entangled by the beauty of this Lady,
The great Thamasta, cherished in his heart
The weight of hopes and fears: it were impossible,
To limn his passions in such lively colours,
As his own proper sufferance could express.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: You are not modest Sir.

sp.speaker: Tham.
sp.l: Am I your mirth?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Love is the Tyrant of the heart, it darkens
Reason, confounds discretion, deaf to counsel:
It runs a headlong course to desperate madness.
O were your Highness but touched home, and thoroughly,
With this (what shall I call it) Devil --

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Hold, let no man henceforth name the word again
Wait you my pleasure, Youth; it is late, to rest.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: My Lords --

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Enough, thou art a perfect Arts-man.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.l: Panthers may hide their heads, not change the skin:
And love pent never so close yet will be seen.

div2.head: Actus IIII. Scena I.

sp.speaker: Amethus.
sp.l: Dote on a stranger?

sp.speaker: Mena.
